sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The ever-increasing energy demand accompanied with the severe emission of contaminants leads to the environmental pollution and global warming.[1–5] The development of advanced energy storage devices (hybrid supercapacitors and secondary batteries) plays a vital role in the better utilization of green and renewable energy sources, such as solar, wind, biomass, and geothermal energy.[6–14] The key is to develop high-performance electrode materials. For electrode materials, the design of nanoscaled structures and the introduction of carbon substrates have commonly been regarded as effective
Electrochemical energy storage is of extraordinary importance for fulfilling the utilization of renewable and sustainable energy sources. There is an increasing demand for energy storage devices with high energy and power densities, prolonged stability, safety, and low cost. In the past decade, numerous research efforts have been devoted to achieving these requirements, especially in the design of advanced electrode materials. Hollow carbon spheres (HCS) derived nanomaterials combining the advantages of 3D HCS and porous structures have been considered as alternative electrode materials for advanced energy storage applications, due to their unique features such as high surface-tovolume ratios, encapsulation capability, together with outstanding chemical and thermal stability. In this review, the authors first present a comprehensive overview of the synthetic strategies of HCS, and elucidate the design and synthesis of HCS-derived nanomaterials including various types of HCS and their nanohybrids. Additionally, their significant roles as electrode materials for supercapacitors, lithium-ion or sodium-ion batteries, and sulfur hosts for lithium sulfur batteries are highlighted. Finally, current challenges in the synthesis of HCS and future directions in HCS-derived nanomaterials for energy storage applications are proposed.

As a crucial family of carbon materials, hollow carbon spheres (HCS) comprise of carbon shells and interior voids, which endow them several unique features, such as high surface area, low specific density, tunable porosity, and good mechanical strength.[15–19] HCS have been employed as the carbon matrix to integrate with other materials. Owing to their unique physiochemical and structural properties, HCS-derived nanomateirals have received wide attention in supercapacitors (SCs), lithium ion batteries (LIBs), sodium ion batteries (SIBs), and lithium sulfur batteries (LSBs). The porous and hollow nanostructures can shorten the diffusion length of electrolyte ions in the electrode materials, improving their electrochemical capacity and rate capability. The carbon shells not only accommodate the volume expansion/contraction in the charge storage process, but also facilitate
the electron transfer. The interplay of these two factors results in prolonged cycling stability and outstanding rate performance. Moreover, the large surface can increase the contact area between electrode and electrolyte, which is beneficial for the utilization of active materials. In lithium sulfur battery, for instance, when employed as sulfur hosts, HCS-derived nanomaterials favor the loading of sulfur in the interior voids and mitigate the “shuttle effect” of polysulfide intermediates.[20–22] In addition, when employed as conductive component, they can improve the electrical conductivity of the cathode.
A myriad of HCS-derived materials with various structures have been synthesized. As shown in Figure 1, HCS-derived nanomaterials are classified into two major categories: HCS (single-shell, double-shell, multishell, and yolk–shell) and HCS-based hybrid materials (HCS-supporting, HCS-coating, sandwich, single-yolk in HCS, and multiyolk in HCS). Since the structural parameters of HCS can be elaborately tailored by templates, hard templates have been used via nanocasting, hydrothermal polymerization of biomass, and modified Stöber coating strategy. Additionally, soft and self templates are widely used to synthesize HCS. For the synthesis of HCS-based hybrid materials, HCS are usually first treated with oxidizing agents (HNO3, KMnO4, and H2SO4) to introduce carboxylic and sulphonic groups, which can serve as binding sites for metal species to initiate nucleation and boost interactions with guest molecules.[23] Encouragingly, HCS-derived nanomaterials with tunable shell structures and chemical compositions have been

Herein, we provide a comprehensive overview of the HCSderived nanomaterials for electrochemical energy storage. First, synthetic methods and rational design for porous HCS are introduced. Afterward, strategies to integrate HCS with other nanomaterials are specified. Benefiting from such unique architectures, the HCS-derived nanomaterials have been applied as electrode materials for supercapacitors, LIBs, and SIBs, as well as sulfur hosts for LSBs. Their advantages are discussed thoroughly. Finally, we finish the review with a brief discussion regarding further directions for HCS-derived materials in energy storage applications.

sections.heading: 2. Synthesis Methods
sections.text: Many parameters of HCS, such as inner/outer diameter, mesoporous structure, and the number of the shells, can be tailored. Design of functional HCS has been a hot research topic. In order to fulfill the requirements for the materials in energy conversion and storage, fabrication of HCS and their derivatives has evolved from simple to complex structures. The method involves adjusting shell and interior architecture. Accordingly, three types of methods (hard, soft, and self-templating) are combined with various preparation technologies (selective etching/dissolution, nanocasting, chemical vapor deposition, layer-by-layer assembly, spray pyrolysis, etc.). According to micromorphology and component, typical examples of HCS and their hybrid nanomaterials are categorized and summarized in Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.1. Hard Templating
sections.text:
Hard templating methods are facile and straightforward to create hollow structures, where the as-prepared rigid particles are utilized as templates and removed after the formation of the desired shells. Taking a single-shelled HCS as an example, the starting template is first coated with a layer of carbonaceous precursor which will be subsequently converted into a carbon shell by the carbonization treatment, followed by selective removal of the template to form a desired carbon nanomaterial with internal void space. Although hard templates need to be removed by tedious processes, HCS with narrow size distribution and good morphological uniformity can be obtained. A great deal of templates can be employed due to their readily fabrication, such as silica sphere, polymer sphere, and metallic sphere.
Silica spheres are generally utilized as hard templates to synthesize spherically hollow structure due to their tunable size from nanometer to micrometer and negative charges on their surface, together with the outstanding thermal stability. Silica cores can be removed by treatment with hydrofluoric acid (HF) or NaOH, leaving behind carbon shells.[46] For instance, Lou’s group used SiO2 spheres, F127-polydopamine (FPC), and 1,3,5-trimethyl benzene as substrate, structural unit for the formation of colloidosome shell, and micelle swelling agent, respectively, to fabricate SiO2@FPC core–shell colloidosome hybrids.[47] Then SiO2@FPC was converted into HCS colloidosome after carbonization and treatment with HF. Dai’s group has first reported the preparation of HCS doped with nitrogen. sections.heading: 2.2. Soft Templating
sections.text:
Although the morphology of HCS can be conveniently tailored by the hard templates, some of hard templates need to be dislodged by acid/alkaline etching or organic solvent dissolution, making the procedure tedious and environmentally unfriendly. By contrast, the soft templating approach is facile and convenient by virtue of the self-assembly of precursor molecules with the aid of colloidal systems as templates, which could be easily consumed and removed by pyrolysis or extraction.[27] These templates mainly include nanoemulsion droplets, micelles, and gas bubbles generating from organic additives or surfactants.

The primary oPD oligomers served as a template by hydrogen bonds, which made the polymer chain propagate form PoPD spheres. Due to the increasing solubility of oPD with the rising reaction temperature, more oPD monomers fled out of the monomer-filled micelles into the aqueous solution, resulting in the formation of PoPD hollow spheres. Followed by carbonization of the PoPD hollow spheres, N&O-doped HCS were obtained whose size was smaller than PoPD hollow spheres (Figure 4e). However, few soft templates are available for self-assembly with carbon precursors into polymeric mesostructures, limiting the development and application of this method. Moreover, the low yield and high cost together with broad size distribution of HCS further restrict its development. Therefore, it is desirable to find other types of soft templates, reduce the cost, and produce uniform size distribution of HCS in the future.

sections.heading: 2.3. Self-Templating
sections.text:
Self-templating method has been recognized as an economic and time-saving strategy to prepare HCS in the absence of either hard or soft templates, which are generally introduced into the reaction medium and removed afterward. In the selftemplating procedure, solid or hollow polymer spheres can be directly synthesized by self-assembly or self-templating method with essential reagents and subsequently converted to hollow carbon spheres by calcination treatment. Sun et al. synthesized HCS based on scalable homopolymer vesicles, which were self-assembled from an amphiphilic homopolymer (poly(amic acid), PAA) and then graphitized under N2 atmosphere (Figure 5a).[28] PAA homopolymer fabricated by stepwise polymerization of two monomers without any catalyst could self-assemble into uniform vesicles simply by adding water into PAA solution. The HCS could be directly obtained by carbonization of the PAA vesicles (Figure 5b). If the PAA vesicles were cross-linked with melamine, they were calcinated into nitrogen-doped porous HCS. The ratio of nitrogen can be determined by controlling the amount of melamine. Ma et al. prepared HCS with microporous graphitic carbon shell and moderate heteroatom content via a simple pyrolysis of solid melamine-formaldehyde (MF) resin spheres synthesized by hydrothermal method.[64] In the process, neither template nor template-agent participated, and a mass-produced polymer with 45% nitrogen (melamine) was used to produce N-doped carbons. The average diameter of prepared HCS gradually decreased with increasing carbonization temperature, mainly resulting from enhanced pyrolytic amount of MF at elevated temperature.
Spray pyrolysis has been employed to the fabrication of HCS due to a simple process and ease of large-scale production. Especially, the template-free spray pyrolysis can generate hollow carbon nanospheres by simply adjusting the precursors. Suslick’s group synthesized porous carbon spheres by ultrasonic
spray pyrolysis (USP) using either halogenated carboxylate salts or simple carbohydrates via a continuous, one-step, and template-free aerosol approach (Figure 5c).[63] The morphologies of HCS were dependent on the choice of propiolate cations with different thermal decomposition temperatures. The relationship between its melting point and decomposition temperature determined whether a core of molten salt would be formed, ultimately leading to a hollow microsphere. Additionally, the relative amount of gas released at a temperature higher than the initial decomposition one determined the microporosity, as the carbon shell became fully compact and cross-linked. Therefore, HCS with different morphologies were obtained by using different precursors, such as HCCCO2Li (Figure 5d), HCCCO2Na (Figure 5e), and HCCCO2K (Figure 5f).

sections.heading: 3. Morphologies and Architectures of HCS and Their Hybrid Materials
sections.text:
Generally, HCS with mesoporous outer shell are favorable for the penetration of electrolyte ions into the interior region of the shell, enhancing the contact area between electrolyte and electrode material. Meanwhile, construction of hierarchical HCS and their hybrid materials with rational pore distribution from micropore to macropore could offer an efficient pathway to reduce the transport resistance of electrolyte ions entering the inner cavity. In addition, employment of multilayer shells can efficiently enhance the packing density, while preserving all the merits of hollow structures. Therefore, the construction of intricate architectures of HCS and their compounds can greatly enhance the overall energy and power density.
HCS and their composites have been rationally designed and successfully fabricated using various strategies, such as template synthesis, spray pyrolysis, emulsion/interfacial polymerization, and self-assembly. These abovementioned approaches are able to precisely control their compositions, shell thickness, core diameter, and overall morphologies of HCS and their hybrids.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Single-Shelled Hierarchical HCS
sections.text:
In general, single-shelled HCS are composed of macroporous voids and microporous carbon shell. For the purpose of efficient mass diffusion and transport of ions and electrons, the augmentation of mesopores in carbon shells has been regarded promising for the interplay of micropores and macropores. As is well-known, microporous structure can improve ion selectivity but limit fast mass diffusion. While the macroporous voids can serve as “ion-buffering reservoirs,” which could shorten the diffusion distance of electrolyte ions. Consequently, construction of mesoporous structure could accelerate the penetration of electrolyte ions from macropores to micropores. Whereas mesopores as channels can facilitate movement of electrolyte ions to reach all the available surface area. Introduction of structure-directing agents into the carbon shell is an effective approach to creating mesoporous structure.

Due to the numerous mechanisms coexisting in the alkoxysilane hydrolysis-condensation reaction and RF base-catalyzed polymerization, well-ordered mesoporous polymer/silica shells can be simultaneously deposited on the surface of templates via the surfactant assistance. Importantly, tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) functions as the pore constructor in the shell-coating process.[76] The silica in shell framework as scaffold for the polymer can effectively restrain the shell shrinkage, and hence the mesopores within the carbon shell could be created after selectively etching the silica component. Li et al. synthesized HCS with tunable porous shells by introducing TEOS in the carbon-coating process (Figure 8a–c).[74] In the synthesis process, CTAB was used both inducing the spontaneous deposition of RF resin and promoting the polymerization of RF at low concentrations. Ammonia catalyzes both polycondensation of RF and hydrolysis-condensation of silica through concurrent reactions. Hence, it is beneficial for the deposition of silica/ polymer layers on the silica core surface. The HCS, obtained with the assistance of additional TEOS, had a very high surface area and abundant pores. Mezzavilla et al. employed a versatile synthetic procedure to fabricate hollow mesoporous carbon spheres (HMCS).[75] The procedure is comprised by the deposition of a homogeneous polymer/silica composite shell on the outer surface of silica spheres via the simultaneous ploycondensation of TEOS and RF, hydrothermal treatment, calcination, and removal silica process (Figure 8d). The thickness of carbon shells (60–110 nm) can be easily tuned by adjusting the summation of reactants, which however could not alter the achieved carbon textures. In the first step, TEOS could rapidly convert into silica spheres, of which the outer surface was covered by NH4+ thereby inhibiting the aggregation of silica spheres and allowing the formation of a stable colloidal suspension. Simultaneously, resorcinol and formaldehyde were catalyzed by the OH− ions and diffused to the surface of silica spheres owing to the electrostatic attraction with the NH4+ ions located on the surface of silica. Finally, an RF polymeric layer around the silica sphere (silica@RF sphere) was formed by the condensation reaction between these species, which occurred in the vicinity of silica particles. Following the carbonization and etching processes, a HCS with well-dispersed and uniform structure was obtained (Figure 9b). There is no additional surfactant used in the synthesis process, which could simplify the synthesis steps and reduce the production cost.
On account of the faster hydrolysis and condensation of TEOS, the formation of silica core and primary particle is difficult to control, resulting in the incorporation of few amounts of silica into the polymer layer which correspondingly produce pores in the carbon shell. Accordingly, Yu’s group used the tetrapropyl orthosilicate (TPOS) instead of TEOS to synthesize mesoporous carbon hollow spheres (MCHS) with adjustable pore size via a facile and one-pot approach (Figure 9c).[26] TPOS can undergo slower hydrolysis-condensation rate than TEOS, and thereby effective control over SiO2 cores and primary species formation was acquired (Step I). Then SiO2 cores were coated by the silica species and RF oligomers after cocondensation to form SiO2@SiO2/RF with core–shell architectures (Step II), which were converted to MCHS after carbonization and selective removal of silica component (Step III). Field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM) image showed that nanosized spikes with sizes smaller than 10 nm were uniformly dispersed on the outer surface of SiO2@SiO2/C spheres obtained from the carbonization of SiO2@SiO2/RF (Figure 9d). After removing the carbon from SiO2@SiO2/C sphere, the sphere with a solid core and a radially porous shell was observed (Figure 9e). The removal of silica component from SiO2@ SiO2/C spheres led to the generation of monodispersed MCHS with mesoporous shell and radial pore channels (Figure 9f,g).
PS spheres solely used as sacrificial hard templates have not been fully utilized, leading to the waste of resources and ineluctable environmental contamination. In fact, PS spheres can also serve as carbon sources by the Friedel–Crafts reaction or dissolution capture method, where polystyrene molecules released from the core of PS spheres can be cross-linked in the space of silica shell. Chen et al. presented a multistep procedure to synthesize HMCSs by the “dissolution-capture” method.[79,81] As depicted in Figure 10a, PS spheres prepared by emulsion polymerization were homogeneously deposited by mesoporous silica layer (PS@SiO2), followed by the dissolution of PS core in tetrahydrofuran to form PS molecules which could be captured in the mesochannels of silica shells (PS@ SiO2-NHs). Then the formation of hyper-cross-linking of PS occurred in the mesoporous shell via Friedel–Crafts alkylation
(HPS@SiO2-NHs), which could produce a sufficiently large molecular weight and avoid decomposition of PS precursor during carbonization. After carbonization and removal of silica, HMCSs were obtained with uniform mesopore size. Chen et al. also used the same protocol to prepare nitrogen-doped hollow mesoporous carbon spheres with high monodispersity, where polystyrene/ployacrylonitrile nanocomposite served as carbon and nitrogen source.[82] Similarly, Chen et al. prepared nitrogen-doped HMCSs via “dissolution-capture” method by selecting the polyacrylonitrile nanospheres as hard template, which could be dissolved in dimethylformamide.[83] To simplify the synthesis procedure of aforementioned method, Wang et al. developed a facile and cost-effective approach via Friedel– Crafts reaction to prepare uniform HMCSs (Figure 10b).[80] In the process, chloroform was used to dissolve the PS cores to form a hollow cavity, and anhydrous aluminum chloride as catalyst was employed to promote cross-linking of PS molecules during Friedel–Crafts reaction. It should be mentioned that the following steps were carried out without separation, including dissolution of PS spheres, adsorption of PS molecules in the mesochannels of silica shell, and cross-linking of PS molecules.
In view of the direct removal of thermal-decomposable soft templates by calcination, the synthesis of HCS with diameters below 100 nm is relatively facile and time-saving via soft templating protocol.[84] Xu et al. designed well-defined hollow carbon nanospheres with highly porous structures via soft template method with carefully selected carbon sources and carbonization parameters.[85] Aniline and pyrrole comonomers as carbon precursors and Triton X-100 as soft template were utilized to fabricate polyaniline-co-polypyrrole (PACP) hollow spheres, whose robust conjugated structure ensured sufficient carbonization of the framework with inherited nanostructure. After calcination of PACP under protection of an inert gas, PACP spheres were converted into hollow carbon nanospheres (HCNs) with well-defined nanospherical morphology and narrow size distribution (Figure 11a–e). The diameters of HCNs were below 100 nm, obviously smaller than their parent PACP, due to the framework shrinkage during carbonization. The specific surface area of HCNs could reach as high as 3022 m2 g–1, much higher than that of PACP (33 m2 g–1), indicating the generation of numerous nanopores in the carbon shell during carbonization treatment. Li et al. also prepared HCNs by utilizing asymmetric triblock copolymer poly(styreneb-2-vinylpyridine-b-ethylene oxide) (PS-b-P2VP-b-PEO) micelle as soft template.[86] By simply changing the solvent, ultrasmall sized micelles of PS-b-P2VP-b-PEO could be obtained and guided the growth of polymer in their peripheries, leading to the formation of hollow polymer nanospheres. After carbonization, HCNs were obtained with ultrasmall outer diameter of 43 nm and hollow core diameter of 19 nm. Hydrophobic PS, protonated P2VP, and hydrophilic PEO were used as the three parts of triblock copolymer. They had the respective functions in the formation of polymer hollow nanospheres: creating hollow voids, accommodating framework precursors, and keeping their stability.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Double/Multishelled HCS
sections.text:
Double/multishell and yolk–shell nanostructured HCS have been rationally designed with diverse internal frameworks, including double-shells, multishells, and multichambers. Analogous to the synthesis of single shell HCS, HCS with complicated architectures can also be fabricated by the wellcontrolled hard/soft template methods.
Layer-by-layer assembly technology has been usually employed to fabricate multishelled HCS by the alternative growth of carbon sources and removable species on the rigid template, followed by pyrolysis and selective etching treatment. Zang et al. synthesized HCS with foam-like shells via a hard templating method by this technology.[30,31] As illustrated in Figure 13a, the SiO2 spheres were first coated with resorcinol-formaldehyde resin and SiO2 layer aided by cationic surfactant (SiO2@RF@SiO2), which could be converted into HCSF after the carbonization and template etching (Figure 13b). By continuous layer-by-layer growth of resin and silica, SiO2@RF@SiO2@RF@SiO2 multishelled spheres were obtained and subsequently transformed into HCS with double and foam-like shells (DHCS) by pyrolysis and selective dissolution (Figure 13c). The hollow-in-hollow structure of DHCS displayed obvious porous shell feature as well as clear void space between core and shell. Yun et al. used the similar approach to initially preparing the SiO2/TiO2 double-shelled
particles, which were then coated by polydopamine layers.[94] Followed by carbonization and selective etching, double-shelled HCS were obtained with nitrogen doping, high surface area, and rich porous structure.
Polymer spheres have been used as starting templates and partial carbon sources to synthesize the double-shelled HCS by the layer-by-layer assembly strategy. The polymers as templates could be directly converted into hollow carbon cores by carbonization treatment, which could effectively trim the synthetic processes compared with the traditional “hard-template” route. As demonstrated in Figure 13d reported by Fang et al., PS spheres with linear soft core and cross-linked hard shell were first coated with silica layer and subsequently encapsulated by polydopamine.[93] During the pyrolysis process, the linear PS soft cores were decomposed to generate the hollow voids, while the cross-linked PS hard shell and PDA were carbonized to form the inner and outer carbon shells, respectively. It is worth noting that double carbon shells were inlaid with silica particles. After etching the silica with HF, double-shell cage-like HCS (DCHCS) with abundant interconnected large mesopores were successfully prepared (Figure 13e).
However, the straightforward layer-by-layer assembly needs tedious and time-consuming operating procedures. Therefore, hollow porous spherical hard templates have been employed to prepare multishelled hollow structures. Polymer layers could be successively deposited onto the inner and outer surfaces of Fe3O4 shells during the continuous consumption of Fe3O4 template, forming the Fe/polymer double-shelled hollow sphere (Figure 15b,c). For instance, Xu et al. developed a simple one-step and “soft-template” approach to fabricate micelles/polymer/silica/polymer with complex architecture, followed by carbonization process and chemical etching to form nitrogen-doped double-shelled hollow mesoporous carbon spheres (N-DHMCSs) (Figure 15f–h).[33] Anionic block copolymer polystyrene-b-poly(acrylic acid) (PSb-PAA) micelles, TEOS, and dopamine acted as soft template, pore-forming agent, and carbon and nitrogen sources, respectively. Copolymer and dopamine could form the micelles (PSb-PAA/DA) as a result of the electronic interaction between the negatively charged PAA blocks and positively charged dopamine molecules. After the addition of TEOS and ammonia, PDA layer and silica layer were formed on the surface of the micelles (PS-b-PAA/PDA/silica). When the silica layer was completely generated, the residual dopamine continuously polymerized to polydopamine near the outer surface of silica shell (PS-b-PAA/PDA/silica/PDA). During the carbonization, polydopamine components from both the inside and outside of silica shells were converted into the carbon layers, while the micelles decomposed into hollow cavities (C/SiO2/C). sections.heading: 3.1.3. Yolk–Shell Nanostructured HCS
sections.text:
Apart from the single- and multishelled HCS, yolk–shell carbon spheres (YSCSs) with unique core@void@shell architecture have stimulated a great deal of interests, due to the combination of micropores, mesopores, and macropores with a controlled arrangement in one single particle. Deploying the typical hard template procedures, the resin spherical template is first coated with a silica layer followed by the deposition of a layer of carbon precursors to form the sandwich-like core@silica@carbon nanostructure, which can be converted into YSCS after carbonization and selective removal of silica. Yang et al. employed a modified hard-templating method to prepare YSCNs, where RF resin nanospheres as templates were encapsulated with a mesoporous silica layer to form RF@ SiO2 core–shell nanospheres (Figure 16a).[34,102] Due to the dehydrogenation and aromatization during the carbonization process, the RF cores were carbonized and shrunk to generate the carbon core with mesoporous feature resulting from the thermal removal of surfactants, and the organic fragments separated from the core during the phase separation process were attached on inner silica shell and simultaneously converted into
the microporous carbon shell. After etching treatment with HF, YSCSs were obtained with microporous carbon shell and mesoporous carbon core (Figure 16b–d).
Apart from hard-templating method, soft-templating method as a feasible and effective strategy is also used to synthesize the YSCS with controlled morphology. Shu et al. prepared N-doped YSCSs with mesoporous structure, where CTAB, RF, melamine (M), TEOS, and ammonia served as a pore-forming agent, carbon source, nitrogen source, a skeleton, and a catalyst, respectively.[35] Because of the different reaction rates between MRF polymerization and TEOS hydrolysis, a CTAB/MRF core and a SiO2/CTAB/MRF shell were gradually formed. The ensuing carbonization and NaOH etching yielded the YHCS with uniform elemental distributions (Figure 16e–g). Liu et al. prepared the N-doped mesoporous YSCS by the introduction of EDA as both catalyst and nitrogen precursor into a Stöber-silica/ carbon assembly system via the soft templating method.[103] The N-doped YSCS had a high surface area of 2001 m2 g–1 and uniform mesopore size of 2.6 nm. Additionally, the sol–gel process combined with soft templating approach has also been utilized to fabricate the YSCS with large particle size and hierarchical porous structure. Wang et al. prepared the YSCSs with a hierarchical porous texture embracing a microporous yolk, a mesoporous shell, and a macroporous hollow cavity between yolk and shell.[104] Xu’s group et al. used the similar strategy to synthesize the N-doped YSCS with the average diameter of 815 nm. The YSCS was composed of a carbon shell of 140 nm and a spherical yolk of 410 nm.[105] Impressively, the interpenetration mesopores were formed by etching the silica particles and transformed into interconnected mesoporous tunnels.

sections.heading: 3.2. HCS-Based Hybrid Nanomaterials with Complex Architecture
sections.text: HCS as important conductive matrix have been used to fabricate various hybrid nanomaterials, due to the unique morphology and structural features combined with the advantages of carbon itself. Introduction of metal particles or their oxides/ sulfides into the HCS allows for the design and synthesis of functional nanomaterials. Hollow carbon structure serving as heterogeneous nucleation centers can effectively prevent the active particles from agglomeration and provide a buffer space for volume expansion. Up to now, a large number of HCSbased hybrid nanomaterials with assorted architectures have been synthesized by rationally designed approaches, such as selective etching, bottom-up or ship-in-bottle, and Kirkendall/ Ostwald-effect-based methods.

Therefore, soft-templating approach was developed by Xu et al. to construct novel yolk–shell nanocomposite.[112] As demonstrated in Figure 17h, metal@polymer composite (Figure 17i) was first prepared via soft-templating method, which was directly converted into metal@carbon yolk–shell composite by carbonization (Figure 17j). Moreover, Ni@ HCS composite was also fabricated by Chattopadhyay et al. via the soft-templating method.[120] Cui et al. realized that novel metal@carbon with multiyolk@shell nanostructure could be fabricated via the template-free method based on nanoscale Kirkendall effect.[121] Due to the displacement of the interface between two different solid phases, multiple Bi particles encapsulated in HCS were prepared by the carbonization of their precursors.
Spray pyrolysis, as a well-known commercial process for large-scale production of spherical ceramics and metal powders, has been employed to fabricate metal@HCS hybrid nanomaterials.[126] The core–shell structure, in which two kinds of metal oxides served as the composite core and an amorphous carbon acted as shell, was first formed via the spray pyrolysis method. Subsequently, one kind of metal could be easily removed by a drying process to generate the heterogeneous yolk–shell microspheres due to the different melting point and evaporation temperature of two metals. Hong and Kang used a one-pot spray pyrolysis process to prepare yolk–shell Sn@HCS microspheres, as illustrated in Figure 18a.[122] Droplets containing Sn oxalate, Zn nitrate, and polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) were first transformed into metal salts@PVP composite due to the outer movement of PVP with a low density, and subsequently converted into metal oxides@C/PVP with core–shell structure under moderate temperature (Figure 18b). Finally, the yolk–shell structured Sn@HCS microspheres (Figure 18c) were obtained by the carbonization of C/PVP shell and the reduction of metal oxide to metal at high temperature in a reducing
atmosphere, where Zn metal was vaporized to form the void space within the microspheres. The authors also prepared Sn nanoparticles filled in the void of yolk-shelled carbon spheres via spray pyrolysis by changing the precursors.[127]
The impregnation or nanocasting method is another effective approach to prepare metal nanoparticles encapsulated in HCS. In brief, the interior cavities of HCS were filled with metal precursors by their solutions or melts, which could be reduced to metal under certain conditions, finally forming the yolk–shell structured hybrid materials. Li et al. prepared a novel composite composed of HCS with encapsulated germanium (Ge@HCS) by the impregnation of germanium precursor into the porous-structured HCS and succeeding calcination (Figure 18d,e).[123] Fu et al. synthesized Cu particles located in HCS by the impregnation approach.[128] The prepared HCS were mixed with copper nitrite solution and dried in air to form CuO@HCS composite due to the capillary effect of porous carbon shell. The obtained composite was annealed in nitrogen to generate Cu@HCS spheres with yolk–shell structure. Diameters of HCS were ≈200 nm while the size of Cu particles 2 nm. Liu et al. prepared the selenium embedded in hierarchical HPCS, which were derived from metal–organic framework via a facile hydrothermal and subsequent carbonization treatment.[16] The shell of HPCS consisted of numerous and crosslinked hollow carbon bubbles, which made Se firmly confined in their voids by vapor-melting diffusion route.
In addition to these composites based on metallic yolk and carbon shell, metal nanoparticles combined with HCS with other architectures have also attracted considerable attention. Zhang et al. prepared the Sn particles embedded in the carbon shell of HCS (Sn@HCS) via a modified one-pot aerosol spray technique without any additional template.[124] The formation of hollow structure resulted from the surface enrichment of some components during the aerosol pyrolysis. Sn grains were uniformly dispersed in the carbon matrix with a small size of 5 nm and a high Sn mass loading of 68.1% (Figure 18f). Yu et al. synthesized NiSb nanoparticles embedded in carbon shell by the redox reaction between nickel-based MOF and SbCl3 to generate NiSb/HCS nanocomposite via simple calcination and galvanic replacement reaction.[129] The NiSb/HCS inherited the merits of Ni-MOFs, i.e., hollow architecture, large surface area, and accessible porosity. Pd embedded in carbon shell (Pd@ HCS) reported by Chen et al. was synthesized by using Pd ions doped covalent organic framework (COF) as precursor and subsequent carbonization.[130] A hollow spherical COF served as the N-doped HCS template, where the eclipsed nitrogen atoms in adjacent layers acted as the coordination sites for Pd cations. During the calcination treatment under protective atmosphere, not only Pd cations were reduced to generate Pd nanoparticles, but also the N-containing organic linkers were simultaneously transformed into N-doped HCS.
Other than the conventional single-shelled HCS incorporated with nanoparticles, double-shelled HCS wrapping nanoparticles with more complex architectures are greatly desirable for their widespread applications. sections.heading: 3.2.2. Oxides or Sulfides Combined with HCS
sections.text:
The synthesis of oxides/sulfides incorporated with carbon shell has become another hot research topic and numerous inspiring works have been reported. HCS as skeletons for the growth of metal oxides have been widely investigated. For instance, our group reported a series of HCS@metal oxides nanospheres with core–shell structures via bottom-up approach by hard template assembly.[36,131–133] HCS@MnO2 nanoflakes were synthesized based on the easy redox reaction between carbon and KMnO4 (Figure 19a–c).[36] NiO and Co3O4 nanosheets supported on the surface of HCS were also prepared. The core– shell structured SiO2@C spheres were chosen as template, where SiO2 cores as sacrificing template were dissolved and carbon shell as the scaffold was reserved in the hydrothermal process.[131,132] The nickel or cobalt precursor was first deposited on the surface of SiO2@C and subsequently SiO2 core was dissolved in the hot alkaline environment. Hereafter, HCS@ Ni- or Co-precursor with hollow architecture took shape. After calcination under N2 atmosphere, HCS@ Ni- or Co-precursor was converted into HCS@NiO (Figure 19d–g) or HCS@Co3O4 nanohybrid (Figure 19h–j). Furthermore, HCS@NiO nanospheres with hierarchical structure were also prepared by a facile chemical bath deposition followed by annealing under protective gas.[133] N-doped HCS employed as hard template were covered by the vertical nanosheets of nickel precursor at room temperature and directly transformed into HCS@NiO by calcination treatment.
By adjusting the growth sequence of reactants on the template, metal oxide@carbon with hollow and spherical structure could be obtained. Lou’s group designed and fabricated TiO@carbon hollow spheres by a multistep strategy, where PS spheres were employed to prepare PS@TiO2@polydopamine spheres and subsequently converted into TiO@HCS with core– shell structure by carbonization (Figure 20a–d).[37] By calcination under a reduction atmosphere at high temperature, the PS cores were completely decomposed forming the hollow cavities. Polydopamine was simultaneously transformed into amorphous carbon shell, and the TiO2 was reduced into conductive TiO. Fang et al. used the same approach to prepare C@TiO2@C hollow sphere with a sandwich-type configuration, where a TiO2 layer was protected by carbon on both sides.[43] Lou’s group also prepared microsized SnO2@HCS with core–shell architecture by the deposition of amorphous carbon on the SnO2 hollow spheres.[134] The sulfonated polystyrene (SPS) microspheres as hard templates were used to synthesize SPS@SnO2 spheres (Figure 20e,f), which could form SnO2 hollow spheres after
the removal of SPS core (Figure 20g). Subsequently, SnO2@ carbon hybrid was obtained by the hydrothermal deposition of polysaccharide on the surface of SnO2 hollow spheres followed by calcination (Figure 20h). Kim et al. used the emulsion template to first synthesize Fe2O3 hollow sphere which was coated with glucose-derived carbon by hydrothermal method to form Fe2O3@carbon nanohybrid.[135] Jin et al. reported the synthesis of hollow CuFe2O4 spheres encapsulated in carbon shells by the similar method, in which CuFe2O4 hollow spheres were first prepared via the hydrothermal approach and second coated with glucose-derived carbon layer by the hydrothermal approach again.[136]
Aerosol spray pyrolysis, a one-step, scalable, and low-cost synthesis method, has been used to prepare metal oxides/ carbon composites. Wang’s group anchored CuO nanoparticles on the outer layer of HCS via the quick formation of CuO and fast carbonization process.[137] In this process, the solution containing copper nitrate, sucrose, and hydrogen peroxide was first atomized to small droplets. The copper nitrate was then thermally decomposed into CuO nanoparticles, while sucrose and hydrogen peroxide serving as gas blowing agent promoted the formation of hollow architecture. More importantly, CuO/HCS was generated in which HCS stemmed from the partial carbonization of sucrose. The short time at a high temperature ensured a rapid precursor decomposition process and subsequently at fast cooling rate under an oxidizing atmosphere made it possible for avoiding the reduction reaction of CuO. Yang et al. utilized the spray drying strategy to synthesize mesoporous Li3VO4/C hollow sphere.[138] The microsized droplets composed of water, Li2CO3, vanadium precursor, and glucose underwent evaporation and solute condensation to generate hollow spherical precursor containing lithium vanadate and glucose. After annealing in Ar atmosphere, the hollow spherical precursor was converted into Li3VO4/C hollow sphere.
The impregnation-thermal decomposition route can easily produce more complicated architecture by refilling the cavities of HCS with functional species. In brief, the mesoporous HCS as hard templates are first impregnated with a solution of inorganic precursors and dried to form inorganic precursor/HCS composite, which could be transformed into inorganic nanoparticle/HCS compound by annealing. The mesoporous shell is cardinal for the solution of inorganic precursor from the external to interior space of HCS due to the capillary effect. A myriad of organic substances encapsulated in HCS with yolk– shell structure were prepared by Fuertes et al., such as Fe2O3, CoFe2O4, LiCoPO4, NiO, and Cr2O3.[38] The metal nitrates and mesoporous HCS were employed as inorganic precursors and hard templates, respectively. As illustrated in Figure 21a, the voids of mesoporous HCS could be fully inserted with inorganic precursors by repeating the impregnation process (Figure 21b,c). After calcination under insert gas, the metal nitrides encapsulated in HCS were decomposed into metal oxides to form metal oxide@HCS compounds with yolk–shell structures (Figure 21d). The carbon shell not only served as a barrier to prevent the aggregation of inorganic species, but also acted as electron highway to facilitate the transfer of electrons. sections.heading: 4. HCS-Derived Nanomaterials for Energy Storage Applications
sections.text: Hollow carbon spheres and their functionalized nanocomposites have been applied in enhanced-performance energy storage and conversion devices, such as LIBs, SIBs, LSBs, and supercapacitors, owing to remarkable properties including high surface area, large controllable inner pore volume, low density, outstanding chemical stability, and excellent mechanical stability.[154–156] In particular, HCSbased nanomaterials with well-ordered mesostructures have attracted researchers’ attentions due to their excellent and complementary performance of the mesochannels and nanosized quantum effect.

sections.heading: 4.1. Supercapacitors
sections.text:
Supercapacitors, also known as electrochemical capacitors, have been regarded as a promising class of energy storage devices due to their high power density and fast charging/discharging kinetics. Electrodes of supercapacitors can be divided into two types based on energy storage mechanisms: electrical doublelayer capacitance and pseudocapacitance. Electrical double-layer capacitance is produced by the electrostatic adsorption of ions on the surface of active materials, while pseudocapacitance is generated from the fast and reversible Faradaic reactions at or near the surface of active materials. Therefore, the electrochemical performance of double-layer capacitor materials greatly depends on the specific surface area, while that of pseudocapacitor materials is determined by the redox reactions accompanied by the intercalation of ions (OH‒ or H+). In this section, we focus on the HCS-based nanomaterials for supercapacitors (Tables 2 and 3).
Conductive carbonaceous materials are generally considered as promising electrode materials for electric double-layer capacitors (EDLCs), which exhibit fast charging–discharging, high power density, and long-term cycling stability. To solve the issues of relatively low energy density, increasing the specific surface area for ionic adsorption plays a vital role in improving electrochemical property. HCS have been widely investigated as electrodes materials for EDLCs because of their high surface area, excellent stability, and good conductivity. To further enhance the energy density for HCS, creating pores on their carbon shell is the most effective approach. Hierarchical HCS with porous shell exhibited excellent electrochemical performance.[24,25,87,157–160] For instance, hierarchical porous HCS

Mesoporous shell hollow carbon spheres (MSHCS) (Figure 25a,b) were prepared via a triconstituent surface coassembly method to coat a layer of carbon source on the surface of monodisperse silica nanospheres.[25] MSHCS possessed large bimodal mesopores of 6.4 and 3.1 nm together with high surface area of 1704 m2 g–1, exhibiting a high specific capacitance of 251 F g–1 at 50 mV s–1 (Figure 25c).
Additionally, tremendous efforts have been devoted to the design and fabrication of HCS with hierarchical porosity, especially mesopores in the carbon shell combining macropores and micropores to enhance the electrochemical performances compared with HCS materials with microporous shell. Hierarchical porous HCS with microporous shells and meso/ macropores reported by Han et al. delivered a specific capacitance of 270 F g–1 at 0.5 A g–1.[46] Liu et al. fabricated HPCSs with micro/mesoporous shells and macroporous void via a facile hydrothermal approach by using silica spheres as hard templates.[77] The HPCSs activated by KOH had a large specific
surface area of 1290 m2 g–1 and showed a high specific capacitance of 303.9 F g–1 at the current density of 1 A g–1, higher than HPCSs (669 m2 g–1 and 240 F g–1 at 1 A g–1). Construction of HCS with well-developed hierarchical pores not only improves the effective selectivity of ions, but also facilitates the ion diffusion and transport through the macropores and mesopores in the charging/discharging process.
HCS materials with heteroatoms and functional groups deliver enhanced capacitance contributed by the additional pseudocapacitance, resulting from the redox reactions of the doped heteroatoms. Nitrogen-doped HCS are typical examples due to the improvement of surface wettability, electrical conductivity, and electron-donor tendency of carbon matrix. Heavily N-doped HCS (HNHCS) were prepared via a cooperative templatedirected coating method by using SiO2 spheres as templates (Figure 25d).[81] The SiO2 spheres coated with ionic liquids and resorcinol-formaldehyde (ILs-SiO2@RF) could be directly converted into NHCS (nitrogen content: 2.01%) or impregnated with melamine to generate HNHCS (nitrogen content: 5.33%). The HNHCS showed an enhanced electrochemical behavior compared with NHCS, indicating more active sites could be generated by the second N-doping (Figure 25e,f). The size match of the pores and the electrolyte ions is promising to achieve a high capacitance. Chen et al. synthesized monodispersed N-doped hollow mesoporous carbon spheres (NHMCSs) using ionic liquids as soft template.[91] NHMCSs with a high surface area of 1158 m2 g–1 and an average pore diameter of 5.0 nm delivered good capacitance of 159 F g–1 at 1 A g–1 and favorable cycling stability (capacitive retention of 88% after 5000 cycles). N,P,O ternary-doped HCS were fabricated by one-step pyrolysis of cross-linked poly(cyclotriphosphazeneco-phloroglucinol) microspheres (donated as PCPP) at different temperatures (Figure 26a–f).[166] The shell thicknesses of NPOHCS were 120, 80, and 40 nm at the calcination temperature of 850, 950, and 1050 °C, respectively. For the single-shelled HCS, the low bulk density is a huge obstacle for their applications in supercapacitor devices demanding high volumetric energy/power density. The rational design of complicated architectures, such as multishelled or yolk-shelled structure, can effectively and directly enhance the volumetric energy/power density of HCS electrodes. Yun et al. reported the synthesis of N-doped carbon double-shelled nanoparticles (NC DS-HNPs) (Figure 27a) by employing SiO2/TiO2 double-shell nanoparticles as templates and polydopamine-coating.[94] NC DS-HNPs electrode achieved a specific capacitance of 202 F g–1 at 0.5 A g–1. The loss in specific capacitance of NC DS-HNPs after 5000 cycles at 1 A g–1 was 7%, lower than that of N-doped carbon singleshelled nanoparticles (NC SS-HNPs) (9%), indicating that the structure of NC DS-HNPs with double shells was more robust than that with a single shell (Figure 27b,c). Nevertheless, most effort has been mainly focused on the design of randomly distributed micropores or small mesopores in the carbon shell, which would generally lead to the sluggish ion transport in pore channels. N-doped double-shelled cage-like HCS with large mesopores in both of the carbon shells exhibited excellent electrochemical performances, including high specific capacitance, good rate capability, and stable cycling property.[93] This improvement can be ascribed to the existence of a central hollow core and interconnected large mesopores in the carbon shell, which served as the first and second level “ionbuffer reservoirs” to reduce the diffusion distance of ions from electrolyte. 3D N,O-doped double-shelled HCS (3D NO-HCS) were fabricated via “in situ replicating” technique using SnO2 hollow spheres as sacrificing templates, followed by the activation with KOH to introduce more micropores in the carbon shell.[95] 3D NO-HCS delivered an unprecedentedly high specific capacitance of 270 F g–1 at a very high current density of 90 A g–1 and a maximum energy density of 11.9. Wh kg–1 at the according power density of 30 000 W kg–1. This improvement could be attributed to the large surface area and easy-accessible micropore surface with faradaic reaction sites, resulting in the ultrafast ion transport from electrolyte to micropores in the carbon shells.

In addition, hierarchical MnO2/NHCS,[133] NiO/NHCS,[131,133] and Co3O4/NHCS[131] with core–shell architectures were designed by our group via a hard-templating approach, which exhibited better electrochemical properties than the pristine metal oxides. Impregnation of metal oxides in HCS to form yolk-shelled composites is also beneficial to enhance the supercapacitor performances of electrode materials. For achieving LIBs with large capacity, high rate, and long span-life, the performances of anodes play important parts. The transport kinetics and structural stability of alternative nanomaterials for LIB anodes, such as functionalized carbon, metal oxides, and metal sulfides, need to be elaborative considered. Therefore, HCS-derived nanomaterials with high theoretical capacity can be considered as promising candidates for LIB anodes due to their exceptional electrical conductivity for accelerating electron transfer and stable hollow nanostructure for buffering the volume change (Table 4).
Graphite is commonly employed as anode materials for LIBs through the intercalation of Li ions. However, the traditional graphite anodes possess a relatively low theoretical capacity (372 mAh g–1) and unsatisfactory power density resulting from sluggish ion diffusion kinetics. Recently, functionalized HCS as anodes have become prevalent. Macro-mesoporous HCS (MMHCS) with high surface area reported by Yue et al. displayed good cycling stability and rate performance.[182] By decorating a macroporous structure on the surface of mesoporous HCS (MHCS), MMHCS exhibited a high reversible capacity of 686 mAh g–1 at 0.5 A g–1 and 189 mAh g–1 at 60 A g–1, which were higher than MHCS (615 mAh g–1 at 0.5 A g–1 and 76 mAh g–1 at 60 A g–1). After 1000 cycles at a current density of 2.5 A g–1, a high reversible capacity of 530 mAh g–1 could be achieved. The mesopores and macropores in MMHCS could increase the reactive areas and shorten the diffusion path of lithium ions, respectively. Yang et al. fabricated 16.6% N-doped HCS by pyrolysis of ZIF-8. The overall design can curb the aggregation of nanoparticles, favor the Li+ diffusion, and facilitate the adsorption of Li ions. 3D N,O-HCS/reduced graphene oxide (3D-NOHCS/rGO) nanomaterials with heteroatom heavily doped and hierarchical pores displayed superior discharging capacity and high rate performance as well as outstanding cycle stability.[183] Thanks to rGO who featured a 2D nanosheet structure, integration of N,O-HCS with rGO could build an interconnected carbon network, which effectively suppressed the aggregation of rGO nanosheets and accelerated the transfer of electrons, improving the cycling stability and rate capability of the composite. Additionally, the effective heteroatom doping not only provided large quantities of active sites for surface redox reactions, but also increased interactions between carbonaceous materials and lithium ions.
Cui’s group investigated the nucleation and growth behavior of lithium in the HCS with nanoparticle seeds inside (Figure 30a).[222] For the HCS without Au nanoparticles, the deposited Li was intercepted outside the HCS and a dendritic morphology during the deposition of Li metal process formed
(Figure 30b); on the contrary, no obvious Li phase appeared on the surface of HCS loaded with Au nanoparticles (Figure 30c), indicating the deposition of Li metal took place inside the HCS. The in situ TEM was used to elucidate the Li deposition process into the hollow spheres. Li ions moved into the nanocapsules and nucleated at Au seeds, resulting in the obvious volumetric expansion due to the lithiation of Au. With the continuous deposition of Li, Au nanoparticles dissolved into Li phase inch by inch and ultimately disappeared, and hence Li metal filled the cavities of HCS. Such nanoencapsulation of lithium metal inside HCS could provide good stability of lithium metal for electrochemical cycling by reducing side reactions, due to the lessened direct contact between Li metal with electrolyte.
Silicon with the theoretical capacity as high as 4200 mAh g–1 has been regarded as attractive material as anode in energy storage devices. However, the structural degradation and instability of the solid–electrolyte interphase caused by the large volume change (≈300%) during cycling as well as poor electrical conductivity inhibited their commercialization. Reducing the size of silica/silicon and introducing a conductive buffer matric can ease pulverization and improve the cycling stability. Therefore, numerous studies have been reported by integrating HCS and silica/silicon. Cui’s group designed a single silicon

The thicker carbon layer acted as electrolyte barrier could effectively decrease the electrode– electrolyte contact area, leading to high Coulombic efficiency and volumetric capacity. Jaumann et al. prepared the nanosilicon inside HCS as a promising anode material for enhancedperformance LIBs.[204] The nanosized silicon nanoparticles encapsulated within HCS delivered a high specific capacity of 1570 mAh g–1 at 0.25 A g–1 with a capacity retention of 65% after 250 deep discharging cycles. A polycrystalline graphene hollow sphere isolated silicon nanoparticle (Si@void@graphene) was synthesized via an in situ pyrolysis and metal-catalyzed graphitization.[207] The Si@void@graphene manifested significantly high rate capacities (1929 mAh g–1 at 1 C and 1266 mAh g–1 at 30 C) and good Coulombic efficiency (99.5%) due to the existence of graphene shell with a thickness of 3.1 nm, which not only provided a stable and electrical structure for the inner silicon nanoparticles but also prevented the electrolyte from redundantly contacting with silicon.
Tin and tin oxide incorporated with HCS stand out as another kind of attractive candidates for anode materials due to the inherited advantages of carbon substrates and hollow structure, including the accommodation of volume expansion upon lithium insertion and the reduced distance of charge transport. For instance, the yolk-shelled Sn@HCS nanocomposite with a distinctive core@void@shell configuration exhibited excellent cycling stability and superb rate performance in contrast with commercial Sn nanopowders.[122] The improved Li-storage performance could be ascribed to its special architecture, where a void space could accommodate the volume change of Sn metal and carbon shell acted as a barrier could prevent the aggregation of Sn nanoparticles. Zhang et al. fabricated ultrasmall Sn nanoparticles uniformly embedded in spherical carbon shell, exhibiting a high lithium storage capacity of 743 mAh g–1 at 0.5 A g–1 and unprecedentedly appealing capacity retention of 92.1% after 6000 cycles at 4.0 A g–1.[124] Apart from the common
merits of HCS, ultrasmall Sn nanoparticles could accelerate the mass diffusion of electrons and lithium ions, resulting in a high utilization of the active material. Lou’s group reported a series of SnO2/C hollow spheres applied as anode materials for LIBs to overcome the pulverization problem, such as SnO2 embedded in the space of double carbon shells,[200] coaxial SnO2@HCS,[194] and bowl-like C@SnO2.[197] The rationally designed architectures not only increased the structural integrity of active materials, but also enhanced the weight fraction of electrochemically active species (SnO2). These SnO2/carbon nanocomposites exhibited excellent lifespan for at least several hundred cycles and superior rate capability.
Other metal oxides combined with HCS have also been widely investigated by scientists and engineers. Liu et al. rationally designed and successfully synthesized hollow TiO2/ graphite carbon (H-TiO2@GC) spheres via a versatile route (Figure 31a–c).[215] The H-TiO2@GC delivered much higher capacities than H-TiO2, indicating a superior high-rate performance for the high-power LIBs (Figure 31d). As shown in Figure 31e, the graphite carbon layers could provide a high electron transport route and stifle the wrapped TiO2 nanocrystals from volume change, leading to the improved rate performance and excellent cycling stability. Liu et al. reported the preparation of sandwich-like C@TiO2@C hollow spheres by hydrothermal carbon-coating method, showing an enhanced lithium ion storage capacity due to conductive carbon support and void spaces.[214] Unique triple-shelled MoO2/C hollow spheres were obtained by the pyrolysis of triple-shelled Mopolydopamine hollow sphere, which were synthesized by a sequential self-templating mechanism for the multishell formation (Figure 32a–c).[210] When evaluated as anode materials for LIB, triple-shelled MoO2/C hollow spheres delivered the average special capacity of 867 mAh g–1 at 0.2 A g–1 and a reversible capacity of 580 mAh g–1 at 0.5 A g–1 after 200 cycles together with nearly 100% Coulombic efficiency. The multishelled hollow structures could provide more void volume and enhanced structural stability compared with normal singleshelled particles. sections.text:

Large volume variations are inevitable for SIB anode materials such as metal alloys, oxides, and sulfides during the repeated Na+ intercalation/extraction process. However, their nanohybrids constructed with HCS scaffolds are capable of accommodating volume change and maintaining stable capacity during long-term cycles. The unique hollow structure can not only enlarge the surface area and multiply the void ratio resulting in better electrolyte wetting, but also provide an intensive and conductive skeleton to restrict volume expansion and accelerate electron diffusion. For example, carbon coated anatase TiO2 hollow spheres (CCAnTHS) exhibited excellent sodium storage performances, which were superior to amorphous TiO2 solid spheres and bare anatase TiO2 spheres.[230] Benefiting from the carbon decoration and the hollow sphere structure, CCAnTHS delivered a specific capacity of 185 mAh g–1 with a coulombic efficiency of 99% at 0.5 C over 500 cycles and a high capacity of 85 mAh g–1 at a high rate of 25 C after 80 cycles. Recently, 2D layered transition metal dichalcogenides coupled with HCS is another hot topic. Yang et al. prepared porous HCS decorated with MoSe2 nanosheets (MoSe2@PHCS), where the uniform and conformal MoSe2 nanosheets coating shortened the mass transport of electrons and electrolyte ions while the mechanically robust HCS matrix accommodated stress from cycling.[233] MoSe2@PHCS showed a high sodium capacity of 575 mAh g–1 at 200 mA g–1 and long-term cycling stability compared with MoSe2 nanosheets, resulting from the synergic effects on account of the combination of HCS and MoSe2 nanosheets. Additionally, encapsulation-type structures have attracted great attention owing to their unique structural feature and fascinating physicochemical properties. Liu et al. fabricated few-layer MoSe2 nanosheets with expanded (002) planes encapsulated in N-doped HCS (Figure 33d–f), showing a high capacity retention of 382 mAh g–1 even at a current density as high as 10 A g–1 and outstanding cycling life at high current densities (501 and 471 mAh g–1 over 1000 cycles at 1 and 3 A g–1, respectively).[232] Except for the aforementioned merits of HCS-based nanomaterials, the core of the encapsulation-type structure could increase the gravimetric energy density of SIBs by enhancing the weight ratio of the active components. Encapsulating SnS2 nanosheets into HCS with yolk–shell structure was reported by Li et al. and delivered good cycling stability and rate performance.[228]
It is well known that the obvious shortcoming of alloyingtype metallic anodes (e.g., Sb and Sn) is their large volumetric expansion during sodium insertion, where the volume can increase up to 390%.[129,240] Such large volumetric variations render the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer coating on the anode materials repeatedly crack, which eventually leads to the exhaustion of sodium ions by repeating formation of SEI. In the light of the merits of yolk–shell structure, constructing yolk–shell structured metal@HCS nanocomposite is a promising approach to solving the issue. Liu et al. synthesized the Sb@HCS nanohybrid anode by a nanoconfined galvanic replacement route.[42] The yolk–shell nanostructured hybrid, composed by Sb hollow yolk completely protected by a conductive carbon shell, maintained a high reversible capacity of 280 mAh g–1 over 200 cycles even at a current density as high as
1 A g–1 (Figure 33g–m). The excellent cycling stability indicated that the substantial void space between HCS and hollow Sb yolk allowed for the full volume expansion of inner Sb and maintained the integrity of the Sb@HCS anode by the formation of a stable SEI film on the outside carbon shell.
Meanwhile, SIB electrode materials with hollow spherical structure and a carbon coating layer have awaked colossal attention due to the increasing amount of active sites and the short diffusion paths for ion transport as well as the conductive matrix for promoting the electron transport and improving the anode stability. For instance, Qiao’s group prepared uniform Na2Ti3O7 hollow spheres assembled from N-doped carbon coated ultrathin nanosheets (Na2Ti3O7@C HHS), which could significantly curtail energy consumption during the diffusion process of sodium ions and increase the overall conductivity.[235] Na2Ti3O7@C HHS delivered higher reversible capacities than its counterparts (Na2Ti3O7 hollow spheres and Na2Ti3O7 solid spheres). It could be concluded that the unique architecture of N-doped carbon-coated ultrathin nanosheets not only enhanced the electrical conductivity but also facilitated the sodium ion diffusion. Ling et al. reported the hierarchical hollow Na2FePO4F/C microspheres for SIBs, exhibiting an intriguing discharging capacity of 120 mAh g–1 at 0.1 C and maintained the capacity retention of 92.5% at 1 C over 200 cycles.[236] Mao et al. fabricated the Na3V2(PO4)3/C porous hollow spheres with the typical NASICON structure, which provided an open 3D framework for sodium ion migration and conductive network for electron transfer.[238] Na3V2(PO4)3/C porous hollow spheres delivered a specific discharging capacity of 99 mAh g–1 at 20 mA g–1 and retained 90% of the initial capacity after 300 cycles.

sections.heading: 4.4. Lithium Sulfur Batteries
sections.text:
Lithium sulfur (Li–S) batteries, assembled by a sulfur cathode (with a theoretical capacity of 1675 mAh g–1) and a lithium anode (with a theoretical capacity of 1675 mAh g–1), have been regarded as admirable alternatives to LIBs, as their energy densities are twice of those of commercial LIBs together with natural abundance and nontoxicity of sulfur. However, the practical application of Li–S batteries has been seriously impeded by numerous technological barriers. First, the low electronic/ionic conductivity of sulfur and its intermediates results in limited sulfur utilization and relatively low specific capacity. Second, the dissolution and shuttle effect of polysulfide lead to the loss of sulfur cathode, which can cause rapid capacity fading and the poor cycling stability accompanied with low Coulombic efficiency. Additionally, the large volume expansion and shrinkage of sulfur during the lithiation/delithiation processes induce the collapse of the electrode structure. Therefore, the host materials of sulfur play a vital role in the development of enhanced-performance sulfur cathode (Table 6).
Lately, HCS with good electrical conductivity and tailored shell structures have been employed as sulfur hosts in the Li–S batteries. HCS could improve the conductivity of the sulfur cathode, restrict the dissolution of polysulfides out of the cathode, and provide sufficient space to accommodate volume variations. Highly graphitized HCS were prepared as sulfur hosts, in which sulfur was encapsulated into graphitized HCS via an in situ solution deposition route.[244] Due to the fast

Meanwhile, the pore size distribution and specific surface area of the sulfur hosts have intense impact on the electrochemical performances of the corresponding cathode materials. The mesopores could improve the initial discharging capacity of sulfur/carbon nanocomposites owing to plentiful specific surface area, and concurrently the micropores could effectively suppress the shuttle effect resulting in improved cycling stability. Zhang et al. reported the synthesis of a composite of sulfur impregnated in porous HCS (S/PHCS) by a facile self-assembly method and a subsequent melt-diffusion strategy.[243] The S/PHCS with a sulfur loading of 50.2% exhibited an ultrahigh discharging capacity of 1450 mAh g–1 at 0.05 C rate and retained a capacity of 800 mAh g–1 at a high rate of 0.5 C after 30 cycles. To have greater control over the sulfur during charging/discharging process, Lou’s group rationally designed and synthesized double-shelled HCS (DSHCS) with complex shell structures as the sulfur host material. This structure effectively encapsulated a relatively high amount of sulfur, suppressed the outward diffusion of polysulfides, and withstood the volumetric changes upon prolonged cycling.[32] Especially, the voids between the double carbon layers offered a huge space for accommodating the volume variations of sulfur during charging/discharging process. The S/DSHCS composite showed excellent electrochemical properties with high discharging capacity and superior cycling stability as well as high rate performance. Similarly, multishelled HCS with ample surface area and adequate total pore volume could be considered as promising host materials of sulfur. Compared with single-shelled and double-shelled HCS, the multishelled HCS can provide extra protection for sulfur. In other words, multiple carbon shells serve as alternating barriers to limit the dissolution of polysulfides. The multishelled HCS encapsulated sulfur composite with a high sulfur loading of 86% delivered a high discharging capacity of 1350 mAh g–1 at 0.1 C and maintained the specific capacity of 846 mAh g–1 at 1 C after 200 cycles with capacity retention ratios of 84%.[249] To improve the interaction between the nonpolar carbon shell and the polar lithium polysulfides aiming to suppress the dissolution of polysulfide intermediates, heteroatomsdoped HCS have been developed as sulfur hosts to provide

More recently, hybrid nanomaterials of polar transition metal compounds and HCS as a conductive scaffold with a high adsorption capability for polysulfides have been broadly employed as sulfur hosts in LSBs. Inspired by such surface-chemistry, HCS incorporated with polar metal oxides/sulfides, such as MnO2, titanium oxide, SiO2, NiS, FeS, and SeS2, can not only adsorb polysulfides more tightly than pure HCS, but also provide markedly improved cycling performances. MnO2 nanosheets grown on the internal/external surface of N-doped HCS (MnO2/ NHCS) as sulfur hosts enhanced the physical restriction of polysulfides by the carbon shell and minimized the loss of polysulfides by the chemical entrapment of MnO2 nanosheets.[253] The S/MnO2/NHCS composite exhibited a higher initial discharging capacity of 1249 mAh g–1 at 0.5 C and relatively more stable cycling property than S/HCS and S/NHCS. Benefiting from the synergistic encapsulation, S/C@TiO2@C with sulfur content of 76.4 wt% retained a high specific capacity of 511 mAh g–1 after 500 cycles at 2 C (Figure 35b). Moreover, metal sulfides integrated with HCS can be considered as promising sulfur hosts, because they can catalyze redox reactions of polysulfides during the discharging process depending on multiple combinations of stoichiometric compositions, crystal structures, and valence state. Qiao’s group reported a unique sulfur host hybrid nanomaterial which composed of nanosized nickel sulfide (NiS) uniformly dispersed on 3D carbon hollow spheres (C-HS). The hybrid was synthesized by an in situ thermal reduction and sulfidation approach (Figure 35c).[145] In such unique architecture, the nanosized NiS provided a high adsorption capability for polysulfides, while the C-HS shell acted as a physical confinement for polysulfides to mitigate the loss of sulfur and meanwhile as a 3D conductive pathway to favor the electron transfer. The linear scan analysis and STEM images of S/NiS@C-HS indicated that sulfur was homogeneously distributed in the NiS@C-HS host (Figure 35d). The S/NiS@C-HS as the LSBs cathode exhibited an excellent cycling stability with a retention of 96% after 300 cycles at 0.5 C (Figure 35e).

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion and Outlook
sections.text:
Herein, synthetic procedures of HCS and their hybrids with transition metal oxides/sulfides have been highlighted. The complex structures of these composites, embracing multishelled, core-shelled, and yolk-shelled structure have been categorized. These materials possess unique properties which guarantee their attractive performances in different energy storage devices, i.e., alkali ion batteries (LIBs and SIBs) and hybrid supercapacitors. The superiority of these materials lies in several aspects as enumerated below. First, porous hierarchical hollow architectures provide much shorter bicontinuous transport pathways for electrolyte ions and electrons, accelerating the rapid electrode kinetics. Second, the HCS skeletons offer additional electrical conductivity and structural stability, leading to high rate performances and long cycling stability.
Despite the significant achievements as summarized above, we have to recognize that the synthesis and application of HCS-derived nanomaterials are still in their infancy. Several challenges are still waiting to be overcome to drive further development in the energy-related field. The simplification of synthesis procedures is the necessary prerequisite to the acquisition of large-scale and low-cost production. As illustrated in Figure 36a, the hard-templating method for the synthesis of HCS is the most straightforward way to precisely tailor the geometric structures, such as morphology, shell number, and thickness, along with gap space between shells. However, it is sometimes tedious, high cost, and time-consuming, inhibiting its extensive use. Although the soft-templating method waives the need for deliberate template removal procedure, the morphologies of HCS are difficult to be adjusted, unsuitable for scaling up. Encouragingly, the newly emerged self-templating method, incorporated with spray pyrolysis, Ostwald ripening, and Kirkendall effect, paves a new way to fabricate HCS-based nanohybrids. This method combines the advantages of hard tempalting and soft templating, including facile procedure, low cost, and high uniformity. However, the construction of HCS-based materials with complex or intricate structures via self-tempalting method is more difficult than tranditional templating method. Therefore, further exploration and improvement of the existing self-templating methods for HCS with desired structures and uniform particle size distribution would be appreciable. As each method is still confronted with the multiplay of complication, tediousness, or uncontrollability, it is highly desirable to develop other facile, versatile, low cost, and scalable approaches for the synthesis of HCS-based nanomaterials. Spray pyrolysis technology holds great promise, because it could be applied to continuous synthesis of HCS and easily scaled up. Especially, spray pyrolysis combined with soft-tempalting or self-templating method can be utilized to directly transform the target precursors into carbonaceous hybrids in one step. Moreover, developing effective strategies (e.g., impregnation, in situ deposition) to combine various functional materials with HCS can bring great advances to the energyrelated field.

For electrode materials, the design of nanoscaled structures and the introduction of carbon substrates have commonly been regarded as effective Electrochemical energy storage is of extraordinary importance for fulfilling the utilization of renewable and sustainable energy sources. There is an increasing demand for energy storage devices with high energy and power densities, prolonged stability, safety, and low cost. In the past decade, numerous research efforts have been devoted to achieving these requirements, especially in the design of advanced electrode materials. Hollow carbon spheres (HCS) derived nanomaterials combining the advantages of 3D HCS and porous structures have been considered as alternative electrode materials for advanced energy storage applications, due to their unique features such as high surface-tovolume ratios, encapsulation capability, together with outstanding chemical and thermal stability. In this review, the authors first present a comprehensive overview of the synthetic strategies of HCS, and elucidate the design and synthesis of HCS-derived nanomaterials including various types of HCS and their nanohybrids. Additionally, their significant roles as electrode materials for supercapacitors, lithium-ion or sodium-ion batteries, and sulfur hosts for lithium sulfur batteries are highlighted. Finally, current challenges in the synthesis of HCS and future directions in HCS-derived nanomaterials for energy storage applications are proposed. Hollow Carbon Spheres
